titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the E. Roy Weintraub Papers, 1930-2019 and undated RL.11763
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Jonathan Cogliano

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-09-04 15:10:06 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: E. Roy Weintraub (b.1943) is Professor Emeritus of Economics at Duke University. This collection consists of his correspondence, research, and writings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is arranged into series: Correspondence, Conferences and Organizations, Writings, and Research and Notes. Series contain name and topic folders sorted alphabetically.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: E. Roy Weintraub (b.1943) is Professor Emeritus of Economics at Duke University and a Fellow at the Center for the History of Political Economy. Weintraub joined Duke in 1970. His work in the history of economics, particularly the mathematization of economics and history of general equilibrium theory, has been influential in shaping the field and bringing historical methods to the foreground of the history of economics. Weintraub also played key roles in building and developing the Economists' Paper Archive and the Center for the History of Political Economy at Duke. He served as Director of Graduate Studies in the Department of Economics from 1972 to 1983, Department Chair from 1983 to 1987, Acting Director of the Institute of Statistics and Decision Sciences in 1987, Director of the Center for Social and Historical Studies of Science from 1995 to 1999, and chaired Duke's Academic Council. From 1993 to 1995, he served as Acting Dean of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences, and in 1992 received the Howard Johnson Foundation Distinguished Undergraduate Teaching Award. He has also been a fellow at the National Humanities Center. Weintraub holds an A.B. in mathematics from Swarthmore College and a Ph.D. in applied mathematics from the University of Pennsylvania (completed under the supervision of Lawrence Klein). He is the son of economist Sidney Weintraub.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The collection's correspondence is restricted for ten years following the date of its creation. Contact Research Services to request permission to view recent correspondence.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The E. Roy Weintraub Papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift beginning in 1984, with the vast majority of the collection arriving in 2019.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], E. Roy Weintraub Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Accessions described in this collection guide: 4-24-1984, 96-170, 2001-0003, 2019-0036, 2019-0083.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: E. Roy Weintraub is the son of economist Sidney Weitraub. The Sidney Weintraub papers are also included in the Rubenstein Library collections.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The E. Roy Weintraub Papers document his career as a historian of economics and mathematics, and professor at Duke University. The collection provides an overview of his professional activities, particularly his research and writings on the history of economics, role in the community of history of economics scholars, and as a faculty member and administrator at Duke.

The collection also documents his communications with prominent economists as research subjects such as Kenneth Arrow, Gerard Debreu, and Lionel McKenzie. Included in Weintraub's communications are exchanges with prominent figures in the history of economics and related communities of scholars such as Roger Backhouse, Bradley Bateman, Anthony Brewer, Arjo Klamer, Mary Morgan, Deirdre McCloskey, and Philip Mirowski.
Along with his own scholarship and writings, the collection documents Weintraub's roles at in the History of Economics Society, at Duke University, and as an editor of History of Political Economy.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Some files from Weintraub's service as Acting Dean are restricted for 25 years from date of creation. Files related to the Duke Board of Trustees are restricted for 50 years from date of creation. Files related to faculty recruitment and personnel reviews are restricted for 75 years from date of creation.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: In accordance with the Family Education Rights and Privacy Act of 1974 as amended, Duke University permits students to inspect their education records and limits the disclosure of personally identifiable information from education records.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection contains electronic records that must be requested through the collection guide and accessed in our reading room. Contact Research Services with questions.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Original audiovisual materials are closed to use. Contact Research Services to request the production of use copies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series documents Weintraub's professional and personal communications. Notable correspondents include Kenneth Arrow, Gerard Debreu, Deirdre McCloskey, Lionel McKenzie, Phil Mirowski, Don Patinkin, Paul Samuelson, and Robert Solow, among others. Also of note is Weintraub's correspondence with his father Sidney Weintraub and other family members. Files are arranged alphabetically. Given the original arrangement of materials, some correspondence was kept in the Writings and Research series.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Correspondence files are restricted for 10 years following their date of creation. Contact Research Services to request access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes Weintraub's professional correspondence. Some personal correspondence with Sidney Weintraub is included since their communications bridged personal and professional purposes. Files were originally grouped by large spans of time but have been arranged into alphabetical name files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series documents Weintraub's scholarly writings, including collaborations with Till Duppe, Ted Gayer, Daniel Graham, and Phil Mirowski, among others, and work as an editor of the journal History of Political Economy. Files are arranged alphabetically by title, preserving original arrangement.

did.unittitle: Articles, Book Chapters, and Other Papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes reprints, copies, drafts, and other related materials for Weintraub's scholarly writings in academic journals, edited volumes, and other outlets. Files are arranged alphabetically by title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes drafts, research materials, and correspondence for books written by Weintraub. Files are arranged alphabetically by title. Copies of Weintraub's books can be found in the current catalog for the Perkins/Bostock Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Sub-series contains electronic records that must be requested and accessed in our reading room. Contact Research Services with questions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes materials from Weintraub's research. Files include notes, interview transcripts, relevant correspondence, and writings by others used in research. Of note is a transcript of an interview with Gerard Debreu.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes notes, interview transcripts, and relevant correspondence used in Weintraub's research. Files are arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes select scholarly writings by others used as reference materials in Weintraub's research. Includes many volumes once owned by Sidney Weintraub. Files are arranged alphabetically.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: In accordance with the Family Education Rights and Privacy Act of 1974 as amended, Duke University permits students to inspect their education records and limits the disclosure of personally identifiable information from education records. Materials with restricted FERPA information in this subseries are labeled below.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Files related to faculty recruitment and personnel reviews are restricted for 75 years from date of creation. Materials with restricted personnel information in this subseries are labeled below.
